intro: Phytolacca nova-hispania, commonly known as the Brazilian pokeweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to South America. It features a thick, fleshy root system and grows to a height of up to 2 meters. The plant has large, heart-shaped leaves with a smooth texture and produces clusters of small, greenish-white flowers. Its berries are dark purple when mature and contain toxic seeds, making it potentially harmful to humans and animals. The plant is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of environmental conditions.
